articles.headline: A Free-Spirited Wanderer Who Set Obama’s Path
articles.snippet: People who knew Stanley Ann Dunham Soetoro well say they see her influence in her son, Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: People who knew Stanley Ann Dunham Soetoro well say they see her influence in her son, Barack Obama.

articles.headline: Panel Seeks New Limits on Anemia Drugs
articles.snippet: Yet both Amgen and Johnson & Johnson avoided the outcome they most feared: a recommendation that the drugs not be used by any cancer patients.
articles.abstract: Yet both Amgen and Johnson & Johnson avoided the outcome they most feared: a recommendation that the drugs not be used by any cancer patients.

articles.headline: Debt Collectors Try to Put on a Friendlier Face
articles.snippet: Just in time for a recession, the debt collection industry is working to shed its reputation for remorselessly hounding people.
articles.abstract: Just in time for a recession, the debt collection industry is working to shed its reputation for remorselessly hounding people.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Just in time for a recession, the debt collection industry is working to shed its reputation for remorselessly hounding people.

articles.headline: White House Offers Plan to Ward Off Credit Crises
articles.snippet: The Bush administration outlined a plan that officials said was meant more to prevent future crises than to address the current one.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration outlined a plan that officials said was meant more to prevent future crises than to address the current one.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After months of watching a growing credit crisis made worse by steadily eroding home prices, the Bush administration responded on Thursday with the outlines of a plan that officials emphasized is meant more to prevent future crises than to address the current one.

articles.headline: As Dollar Hits New Lows, Investors Look Elsewhere
articles.snippet: As the dollar weakens, holders of dollars, especially those overseas, are aiming for better returns by diversifying their portfolios.
articles.abstract: As the dollar weakens, holders of dollars, especially those overseas, are aiming for better returns by diversifying their portfolios.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  How low can the dollar go?

articles.headline: Global or Local? For Accounting Firms, It All Depends
articles.snippet: That big accounting firm may boast having offices around the world — until an office is sued.
articles.abstract: That big accounting firm may boast having offices around the world — until an office is sued.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is the era of the global firm, whether in finance or industry. A company like Toyota or Citigroup may have its headquarters in one city, but it has operations all over the world and gets capital from a similarly broad base. When Citi ran into difficulties, it turned to Abu Dhabi.

articles.headline: Terror Suspect Eludes Posse of 4 Million
articles.snippet: Singapore’s government has put the entire country on alert after a man believed to be the leader of a terrorist group escaped from prison.
articles.abstract: Singapore’s government has put the entire country on alert after a man believed to be the leader of a terrorist group escaped from prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE  The big mistake, officials here say, was letting the terrorist suspect make a trip to the bathroom.

articles.headline: Gold Glitters, Dollar Loses Its Luster
articles.snippet: Gold has always been a refuge in troubled times. And on Thursday the treasure of millennia finally ticked past the millennium mark.
articles.abstract: Gold has always been a refuge in troubled times. And on Thursday the treasure of millennia finally ticked past the millennium mark.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eighty feet below the sidewalks of Lower Manhattan lie half a million bars of gold, the most valuable stockpile of bullion in the world.

articles.headline: Economy Hammered by Toxic Blend of Ailments
articles.snippet: On Thursday, the dollar plumbed new lows, the price of gold jumped above $1,000 for the first time and lenders raised home loans once again.
articles.abstract: On Thursday, the dollar plumbed new lows, the price of gold jumped above $1,000 for the first time and lenders raised home loans once again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost everything seems to be going wrong for the American economy at once. People are buying less, but most things are costing more. Mortgage rates are rising, the dollar is falling and prices of key commodities like oil are leaping from one record high to the next.
